skills.name: Interpret linear sections of real life graphs
Calculate the gradient on a linear section on a real life graph

explanations.A: The volume of water is decreasing, so the plug has been pulled out
explanations.B: I think you are looking at the wrong part of the graph. When the taps are turned off, the volume of water will say the same, it won't decrease
explanations.C: Not quite. Look at the label of the y axis. It is not measuring temperature.
explanations.D: Not quite, when the bath is filling with water, the volume will increase.

explanations.A: Not quite. Look at the label of the y axis. It is not measuring temperature.
explanations.B: If sand is added, think about what will happen to the mass of the bucket - will it increase or decrease?
explanations.C: When sand is tipped out, the mass of the bucket will decrease, which we can see by the negative slope.
explanations.D: Not quite. When the bucket is full, the mass will remain constant.

explanations.A: Not quite, if the plug has been pulled out, the volume will start to decrease
explanations.B: When the taps are turned off, the volume remains constant, so the graph will show a horizontal line.
explanations.C: Not quite. Look at the label of the y axis. It is not measuring temperature.
explanations.D: Think about what happens to the volume of water when the bath is filling. Would you expect the water volume to remain constant?

explanations.A: Not quite. Look at the label of the y axis. It is not measuring temperature.
explanations.B: Not quite, if sand is being added the mass would increase. In the horizontal section the mass is staying the same
explanations.C: Think about how the mass will change when sand is tipped out - the bucket would become lighter. What would this look like on the graph?
explanations.D: When the bucket is full, the mass will not change so the slope will be horizontal

explanations.A: I think you've found the total cost for this taxi journey. How much is it increasing by with each mile?
explanations.B: Not quite, look again at the scale for the cost. How much will each square represent?
explanations.C: I think you've tried to calculate the gradient, but have not been accurate enough when counting squares. Find a bigger triangle that crosses through the grid lines exactly.
explanations.D: The cost per mile is shown by the gradient of the graph. We can look for a triangle going from 0-5 miles and from £2-£6. The gradient would be rise/run or 4/5 which is 0.8 so £0.80 per mile. You could also think of this as how much more expensive it is for each mile

explanations.A: I think you've tried to calculate the gradient, but have not been accurate enough when counting squares. Find a bigger triangle that crosses through the grid lines exactly.
explanations.B: The cost per mile is shown by the gradient of the graph. We can look for a triangle going from 0-5 miles and from £2-£4. The gradient would be rise/run or 2/5 which is 0.4 so £0.40 per mile. You could also think of this as how much more expensive it is for each mile
explanations.C: I think you've found the total cost for this taxi journey. How much is it increasing by with each mile?
explanations.D: Not quite, look again at the scale for the cost. How much will each square represent?

explanations.A: The volume is measured from the y axis scale. Calculating the gradient gives us the rate of how the volume changes over time
explanations.B: The gradient calculates a rate, the positive slope shows the rate the volume of water in the bath is increasing.
explanations.C: Not quite. Look at the label of the y axis. It is not measuring temperature.
explanations.D: You're on the right track. The gradient will calculate the rate, but think about if a positive slope will show a decreasing volume.

explanations.A: Not quite. Look at the label of the y axis. It is not measuring temperature.
explanations.B: You're on the right track. The gradient will calculate the rate, but think about if a positive slope will show a decreasing mass.
explanations.C: The mass is measured from the y axis scale. Calculating the gradient gives us the rate of how the mass changes over time
explanations.D: The gradient calculates a rate, the positive slope shows the rate the mass of sand in the bucket is increasing.

explanations.A: Not quite, the volume of water flowing is constant. A curve shows changes over time.
explanations.B: When water flows at a constant rate, the graph will be linear (straight line)
explanations.C: Not quite! Only one person is correct. A constant rate means the volume of water flowing is not changing
explanations.D: Not quite, one person is actually correct. A constant rate means the volume of water flowing is not changing

explanations.A: Tom's graph shows the mass is decreasing over time. It is a straight line which represents a constant gradient, so a constant rate. Katie's graph shows that the mass stays the same; it is not changing at all.
explanations.B: Not quite, Katie's graph shows the mass stays the same, so there is no change in the mass.
explanations.C: Not quite, only one graph shows a change in mass over time. Look at the y axis. Is the mass changing in both graphs?
explanations.D: Not quite! One of them is correct. Think about how the graph would look if the mass was decreasing at a constant rate
